description:
Takifugu flavidus, also known as the yellow puffer or yellow-bellied puffer, is a species of pufferfish that belongs to the family Tetraodontidae. This marine fish is native to the western Pacific Ocean, specifically found in coastal waters around Japan, Korea, and China.

Takifugu flavidus is a small-to-medium sized pufferfish, typically measuring between 15 to 30 centimeters in length. The body is laterally compressed and can be inflated when the fish feels threatened, a defense mechanism common among pufferfish species. The dorsal surface of the body is yellowish-brown in color, while the ventral side is bright yellow, hence the common name "yellow-bellied puffer."

Like other pufferfish, Takifugu flavidus possesses the ability to produce tetrodotoxin, a potent neurotoxin, which makes them potentially dangerous for human consumption. This species is commercially important in certain regions, particularly in Japan, where it is highly prized as a delicacy when properly prepared by skilled chefs.

Takifugu flavidus inhabits coastal areas, often found in rocky or reef-associated environments, where it feeds primarily on small crustaceans, mollusks, and other invertebrates. The species is known to be solitary and territorial, and it plays a role in the overall ecosystem dynamics of its native habitats.
